instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V3_G3H: What is 3V3_G3H? This is one of the first power rails that must turn on for Macbooks that use USB-C for charging. This power rail powers the CD3215 chip that controls the USB-C charger, speaks to the USB-C charger, and requests 20 volts up from the default 5 volts that the USB-C charger puts out when initially connected to an unknown device. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.CHGR_ACOK: What is CHGR_ACOK? This is identical to SMC_BC_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .

threads.title: Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
threads.message:
Hi, took the board out and will be measuring just the board with an USB-C amp meter connected to a Powerbank.

Water damaged board with a lot of corrosion around the <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> and a little bit next to the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
USB-meter shows 5V for a few seconds and then powers off and back on again. This will continue cycling.
Checked the resistors and traces next to <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> that seem fine.

Any help where to start would be greatly appreciated.

PS. Have played around a little bit with other Macbook boards, but still a total noob and these USB-C boards are totally new and intimidating to me.

Thanks!

threads.title: Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
threads.message: Anyway you can upload picture of the liquid damage? I would guess corrosion elsewhere as well. <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> for sure can cause this issue if it's bad, so I would replace it from a donor 00875. <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3 volts? Any signs of corrosion near U31/200?

threads.title: Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
threads.message:
If cycles, usually means board tries to start and something blocks the charger and restart.
<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> voltage?
Any short, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> or other rail?
Post some voltages around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
threads.message:
Thanks for the replies!

The board got some very sticky liquid on the areas I mentioned and looks very clean everywhere else. And it does not seem to be cleaned before.
Photos attached.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = 0V and missing. Sorry for not understanding where it is created.
(<CHIP>U7650</CHIP>?)

No shorts atleast on these rails. Should I measure more?
(Any tips which rails are good to measure shorts or should I just measure all of the S5/S4 rails.)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>

Here are some voltage measurements:

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>= 5V

Close to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>:

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> = 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACOK</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_R_L</SIGNAL> = 3.4V

threads.title: Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
threads.message:
I did not have a 00875 donor board to get a new <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
So I scrubbed the corroded places with alcohol and toothbrush and reflowed the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP>.
That did the trick and I got 15V from the charger and the board is working perfectly now!

So corrosion under the <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> was probably the culprit.

Thanks for the help John and 2informaticos! Thread can be closed.

threads.title: Water damage <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Dead board
